question: What is the name of the second tallest mountain in the world?
info: K2, at 8,611 metres above sea level, is the second-highest mountain on Earth, after Mount Everest.

question: What type of leaf is on the Canadian flag?
info: The specific design of the maple leaf that appears in the centre of the National Flag of Canada is known as the stylized 11-point maple leaf.

question: In which European city was the first organized marathon held?
info: The first organized marathon was held in Athens at the 1896 Olympics, the start of the Games' modern era.

question: What is the capital of Peru?
info: Lima, the capital of Peru, is located at an elevation of 528 feet (161 meters) in the Central West part of Peru.

question: In which city would you find La Sagrada Familia?
info: The Sagrada Família is Antoni Gaudí's best-known work and has become an undisputed symbol of Barcelona.

question: What country has the most natural lakes?
info: About 9% of Canada's surface area is covered by lakes. The Great Bear Lake is the largest lake in Canada.

question: What is the only sea without any coasts?
info: the Sargasso Sea is bounded to the west by the Gulf Stream; on the north, by the North Atlantic Current; on the east, by the Canary Current; and on the south, by the North Atlantic Equatorial Current.

question: What is the driest place on Earth?
info: The driest place on Earth is a location in Antarctica known as the “Dry Valleys.” It has not rained there for at least two million years.

question: Which African nation has the most pyramids?
info: Yup, the country with the most pyramids in the world is Sudan,has between 200 to 255 known pyramids, compared to Egypt's 138.

question: What mountain is closest to the Moon?
info: Mount Chimborazo is the closest place on earth to the moon. This is because of a bulge on the earth where the mountain is located on, makes it the point closest to 'outer space'.

question: In the state of Georgia, it’s illegal to eat what with a fork?
info: Yes, in Gainesville, Georgia, you can get arrested for eating fried chicken with anything but your hands. In 1961, Gainesville passed a law making it illegal to use fork to eat fried chicken as a way to promote Gainesville as a “poultry capital of the world”.

question: When was “OMG” first used?
info: O.M.G.!! The first attested use of this was in a letter from John Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher to Winston Churchill in 1917.

question: What animal has the largest eyes in the world?
info: Researchers say that colossal squid (Mesonychoteuthis hamiltoni) have the largest eyes ever studied in the animal kingdom. Measuring 27cm in diameter, each eye is roughly the size of a soccer ball!

question: What animal can not stick their tongue out?
info: Crocodiles can not stick out their tongue or chew

question: Whose eyes are bigger than its brain?
info: An ostrich's eye is bigger than its brain. Compared to other birds, ostriches aren't the smartest, but they have excellent eyesight.

question: What was the last letter added to the English alphabet?
info: “Z” may be the last letter in alphabetical order, but the last letter added  was actually “J.”

question: Where were Doritos invented?
info: The original product was made at the Casa de Fritos (now Rancho Del Zocalo) at Disneyland in Anaheim, California, during the early 1960s.

question: What animal's heart is located in its head?
info: A shrimp has it's heart on its head. Looking at the anatomy of a shrimp we can see that its heart is located behind the brain.

question: What  is Odontophobia?
info: People with odontophobia, also called dentophobia, have a fear of dentists.

question: What is the only animal that can’t jump?
info: Elephant, in fact, it's impossible. Unlike most mammals, the bones in elephant legs are all pointed downwards, which means they don't have the 'spring' required to push off the ground.

question: Who was the Ancient Greek God of the Sun?
info: Apollo was the god of practically everything – including sun and light (although the god is always associated with the sun, the original sun god was the titan Helios, but everyone forgot about him).

question: What year was the United Nations established?
info: Four months after the San Francisco Conference ended, the United Nations officially began, on 24 October 1945.

question: What is a group of crows called?
info: A group of crows is called a “murder.” There are several different explanations for the origin of this term, mostly based on old folk tales and superstitions.

question: How many elements are in the periodic table?
info: with 118 known elements, periodic table is widely regarded as one of the most significant achievements in science.

question: What country drinks the most coffee per capita?
info: Finland is the world's biggest consumer of coffee on a per-person basis. The average Finn drinks nearly four cups a day.

question: Which planet in the solar system is the hottest?
info: Even though Mercury is closer to the Sun, Venus is the hottest planet with an average temperature of 464 degree Celsius!

question: How many bones do we have in an ear?
info: 3 bones are present in the ear ossicles namely, stapes, incus and malleus. The ossicles are also known as auditory ossicles.

question: What country has won the most World Cups?
info: Brazil are the most successful nation in World Cup history and have won the famous trophy five times!!

question: How many hearts does an octopus have?
info: An octopus's three hearts have slightly different roles. One heart circulates blood around the body, while the other two pump it past the gills, to pick up oxygen.
